error.msg: The code 'class BaseNode abstract {' is not handled. You can use -I or --include to add handling of this code.
error.verbose: The code 'class BaseNode abstract {' is not handled. You can use -I or --include to add handling of this code.

error.msg: The scope of the variable 'j' can be reduced.
error.verbose: The scope of the variable 'j' can be reduced. Warning: Be careful when fixing this message, especially when there are inner loops. Here is an example where cppcheck will write that the scope for 'i' can be reduced:\012void f(int x)\012{\012 int i = 0;\012 if (x) {\012 // it's safe to move 'int i = 0;' here\012 for (int n = 0; n < 10; ++n) {\012 // it is possible but not safe to move 'int i = 0;' here\012 do_something(&i);\012 }\012 }\012}\012When you see this message it is always safe to reduce the variable scope 1 level.

error.msg: The scope of the variable 'duplicate' can be reduced.
error.verbose: The scope of the variable 'duplicate' can be reduced. Warning: Be careful when fixing this message, especially when there are inner loops. Here is an example where cppcheck will write that the scope for 'i' can be reduced:\012void f(int x)\012{\012 int i = 0;\012 if (x) {\012 // it's safe to move 'int i = 0;' here\012 for (int n = 0; n < 10; ++n) {\012 // it is possible but not safe to move 'int i = 0;' here\012 do_something(&i);\012 }\012 }\012}\012When you see this message it is always safe to reduce the variable scope 1 level.

error.msg: Variable 'value' is assigned in constructor body. Consider performing initialization in initialization list.
error.verbose: When an object of a class is created, the constructors of all member variables are called consecutively in the order the variables are declared, even if you don't explicitly write them to the initialization list. You could avoid assigning 'value' a value by passing the value to the constructor in the initialization list.

error.msg: Variable 'type' is assigned in constructor body. Consider performing initialization in initialization list.
error.verbose: When an object of a class is created, the constructors of all member variables are called consecutively in the order the variables are declared, even if you don't explicitly write them to the initialization list. You could avoid assigning 'type' a value by passing the value to the constructor in the initialization list.

error.msg: Class 'RootNode' has a constructor with 1 argument that is not explicit.
error.verbose: Class 'RootNode' has a constructor with 1 argument that is not explicit. Such constructors should in general be explicit for type safety reasons. Using the explicit keyword in the constructor means some mistakes when using the class can be avoided.

error.msg: Prefer prefix ++/-- operators for non-primitive types.
error.verbose: Prefix ++/-- operators should be preferred for non-primitive types. Pre-increment/decrement can be more efficient than post-increment/decrement. Post-increment/decrement usually involves keeping a copy of the previous value around and adds a little extra code.

error.msg: Cppcheck cannot find all the include files (use --check-config for details)
error.verbose: Cppcheck cannot find all the include files. Cppcheck can check the code without the include files found. But the results will probably be more accurate if all the include files are found. Please check your project's include directories and add all of them as include directories for Cppcheck. To see what files Cppcheck cannot find use --check-config.
